Hearts of Iron IV is quite simply the best and most comprehensive strategy game based on World War II. Now that nine years have passed since the game's launch, Paradox has added numerous features that help create the feeling of managing your country, and there is really nothing like it in terms of recreating the scale and scope of the war.

There are essentially 2 games within HOI; the first is a relatively accurate and historical portrayal of the first part of World War 2. The enemy AI is initially locked into choosing the same path their nation took in WW2 through the focus tree, though it should be noted that the various "story beats" can be a little out of time with the real events. The second game is a completely open strategy game set during the Second World War. Do you want to recreate the Mughal empire, or allow Gandhi to forget his pacifism and become the destroyer of worlds he was meant to be? Would you like to endure a 2nd Russian Civil War and bring the Tsar back to power? Within the 4 ideologies in the game (Fascism, Communism, Democracy and Non-aligned), there are a plethora of obscure historical or completely wacky goals for you to achieve, and I like that the achievements encourage you to try out these paths. 

The game can be as complex as you like, allowing you to meticulously plan operations such as Barbarossa, subdividing your army groups into separate thrusts with strategic towns or supply hubs to capture. The Eastern Front is just as much of a void into which you throw men and material as reality, and if you want to learn the names of obscure Russian towns, there is no better game. You can fully relive D-Day and the liberation of Western Europe, pushing back the veil of totalitarianism. 

Terrain such as mountains, deserts and jungles all have direct impacts on combat, and the game has a dynamic weather system that calculates rainfall, mud accumulation and snowfall. You can give divisions and their commanders medals if they participate in an action worthy of merit. 

The supply and logistics system is deep and complex, with the game even taking into account the flow of supply up and down rivers, should you own both banks. 

Tank, plane, and ship designers allow you to recreate historical vehicles or create monstrosities that should never have seen the light of day. 

There is a resistance mechanic, linked to occupation laws, compliance and harshness of occupation. 

There really is so much to learn and adapt to in terms of the limitations of the period, geography and strategic situation. 

Nations have a focus tree, which is where the main "flavour" and historical (or ahistorical) grounding is laid out. Starting in 1936 or 1939, you must guide your nation by managing the economy, building an armed force and guiding your political and strategic aspirations through World War 2. This is where the main historical (or ahistorical) flavour is delivered, and Paradox have really leaned on this mechanic imported from EUIV. 

As a fan of history, I love discovering the obscure history of nations that had marginal roles in the war, and events that I'd never heard about, that had a large impact on their respective nations but were somewhat drowned out by the more momentous battles. There are very few nations left now without focus trees, and old major nations like Germany and Japan have had their focus trees ballooned to keep pace with the new additions. 

All of this barely scratches the surface, and we haven't even gotten to the mod scene yet. HOI4 has some of the most obsessive and creative mods in any game, allowing you to play a strategic game of whatever alternate fiction you desire. Cold War, WW1, Modern Day conflicts like Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, Fallout, Lord of the Rings, My Little Pony, Kaiserreich, all have their respective mods and communities that add many more hours of content. 

Probably my favourite strategy game ever. Get it.

Unfortunately, I find it necessary to post a review of this and the DLC at this point as the changes and discussion have signaled that this is an intended feature and as such I will be reviewing the game assuming it is intended. While I understand few players actively micro, the battle planner, a feature that allows you to build up a bonus to your units stats while on attack over time if you let them sit on the border with an enemy and put them under Ai control, is a frustrating nightmare of a feature that punishes you for microing through tedium and what are effectively stat penalties. While delegating units to be under AI control is a helpful feature Paradox has decided that it is necessary to balance the game around this feature. 

The first issue is that in order to build up planning bonus you have to assign units to a frontline which gives the AI control of where those units will be placed before the offensive starts. The AI will place units in attrition, place them in bad locations, and simply control everything. The approved way around this would be to manually create many separate small frontlines to gain planning bonus, this takes time and creates a dizzying nightmare of attack orders and frontlines overlapping that are hard to control. As a battle plan is executed and provinces are taken the frontlines will dynamically change and I will have to readjust the lines every couple of seconds. This creates a situation where I am effectively fighting against the battle planner. I will be honest, If this is an intended balance feature as others have mentioned it is an awful design choice. It is mind boggling, no other strategy game has ever introduced tedium as a balance mechanic, the only places you will see such things are in risk vs reward scenarios in games and grindy mmos. No other developer that I can think of has ever done this and for good reason.

The second issue lies with the idea to penalize directly taking control of your units in the first place, generally the reason for doing so is argued to be that microing is so much more effective that the stat penalties are justified. The scale of the stat buffs for using your planning bonus makes this argument dubious but also this argument only makes sense when the situation is player vs player where some players are microing and some are letting the AI control areas of the attack. In the single player aspect what this argument actually boils down to is they want to lesson the opportunity cost of not microing your units (It also could be an indirect buff to the AI but this doesn't make much sense to me). Thus, I am not supposed to engage at a more in depth level with what is the core feature of the game in a strategy game. This also boggles the mind as I don't know what game exists bellow this. This isn't meant to knock at players who only use the battle planner its just that I can no longer really engage with the mechanics I enjoyed.

If this is to be assumed to be the intended game design then the game is a frustrating nightmare where you are nearly forced to play at a few layers abstracted away from the actual game, the intended design wants you to have to fight with the AI controlling your units in order to get what you intended done.
